title: Are there transphobic references in Harry Potter or other J.K Rowling books? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, there aren't any OVERT transphobic references in the HP series. Trans people aren't mentioned at all… there are a couple of scenes where someone uses Polyjuice Potion to temporarily masquerade as a person of a different sex, like Crabbe and Goyle disguising themselves as girls in HBP or Fleur and Hermione becoming Harry in DH, but nobody really seems to think there is anything particularly off-putting about this. That said, there are a few scenes and descriptions that, when you read them knowing about JKR's transphobia, kind of read a little…weird. Like others have mentioned, Rita Skeeter can come across as a mean-spirited parody of a trans woman, with the references to her masculine traits like large hands and a square jawline clashing against her super-feminine clothing and mannerisms, and fake-looking hair. Not to mention, she spends much of the book in a shape not her own, spying on school children. Now, I don't know if JKR actually intended for Rita to be trans, but I kinda doubt she did. I think it's just subconscious transphobia colouring her writing here; she wants to make sure Rita reads as thoroughly unsympathetic, and so she lets the narrative mock her appearance:look at this mannish woman pretend that she's feminine. It's a very common tactic for her to make fun of people's looks if she wants them to come across as unsympathetic; the sympathetic characters don't tend to be supermodels either, but they're generally described in more neutral terms or not at all. So that one of the unsympathetic female characters is mocked for having masculine traits… Kind of reads a little differently when you know JKR's attitude with trans people. So any transphobic content in HP is more inferred than actually stated. Such benefit of the doubt cannot, however, be given to her adult novel, The Silkworm, which does include a trans woman character, Pippa, and that portrayal IS transphobic. I might have forgiven that Pippa is portrayed as violent and emotionally unstable, because the book is full of nasty and unlikeable ciscender people too… but I notice that Pippa's appearance is also mocked with her large hands and protruding Adam's apple called attention to (the main female character has problems not laughing), and while the problems she faces as a trans person are alluded to they are mostly played for laughs, and Pippa's mostly just presented as pathetic. The main characters do display some sympathy, but they do so in a very condescending, patronising way while also mocking her, treating her with contempt, and (this is the big one) alluding to prison rape in order to get her to cooperate. Consciously or not, I think The Silkworm most clearly reveals JKR's actual opinion on trans people: she doesn't wish any particular harm on them, and is happy to allow them to exist… But obviously she doesn't think they have any right to be taken seriously, and they mostly deserve to be patrionized and mocked because OBVIOUSLY they're delusional reality-deniers.

Well, it’s complicated. Certainly J.K. Rowling never expresses transphobia openly, but only by not acknowledging the existence of trans people. And in a story where human transfiguration is taught in the same way AP Chemistry is taught in high schools, that is remarkable. There are Metamorphs—people born who can naturally change their appearance at will. It’s notable that the Metamorph we have, Tonks, never once expresses interest in being a boy. We also have Polyjuice Potion, which is apparently only as difficult as an advanced chemistry project, and yet we don’t hear of people changing their bodies using this, even though even cis people would probably be curious enough to try changing their sex for the afternoon. And despite the fact that witches are just as capable with their wands as wizards, just as dangerous, J.K. Rowling chose to have a world whose sexism and gender roles are if anything more regressive than our own, at least in the main series. How long do you think women would have waited for the right to vote if we could cast hexes? Would rape really be a problem if there were Stunning spells? Arguably the wizarding world should transform gender, but J.K. Rowling doesn’t seem interested in exploring that. I don’t think I’d go so far as to say Harry Potter isn’t transphobic, because that’s like saying a work isn’t racist because it doesn’t have any black people. The absence of those people is in and of itself transphobic! And despite what other answers have said, you can’t really disentangle your politics from your writing, it’s too personal. As for them being children’s books, there are trans children. There’s nothing inappropriate about having trans characters in a children’s book, just like there’s nothing inappropriate about having a kid’s picture book where the character has two dads.

One can always manipulate the narrative & present it as something entirely different. Eg. One answer here compares the description of Rita skeeter to transphobia. It's too far fetched!! The description of madame maxime is described in a masculine way but she is portrayed positively. Similarly, tonks who can change her appearance at will is shown baddass. Metamorphs and merpeople in goblet of fire are shown in a positive light. (No relation to transphobia at all). The only negative characters are the death eaters and people like umbridge because of obvious reasons. As for why there is a lack of lgbt representation in the books, it's because even though Dumbledore is not mentioned openly gay but he isn't mentioned straight as well. The Harry Potter books always made it very clear what she thought of feminine traits in cis men and masculine traits in cis women, at the very least. The way she writes shapeshifters, they are wretched beings, with the two morally good ones being massively insecure. “Am I good? Am I okay? Do I even deserve to support the Light? What if all this darkness in me and my uncontrollable murderous rage is who I really am?” Could have been interesting. Wasn’t. Now, Lupin could always have just been for revenge on her math teacher or something, but Tonks also does not get a happy ending. Tonks popped out a baby and ran off to fight, of course she wasn’t going to survive. You don’t just leave a newborn, that’s like the cardinal rule of fiction. If you so much as turn your back for a moment while the audience’s attention is on you, all you get is a movie of long sad shots of sunlit green grass and violin music. And Lupin ran out on them twice, he didn’t want to be there, you think she didn’t notice that? Some marriage. But you’re right, it’s way too subtle to call Rowling on. All cis straight couples get to be happy together forever, though. Even Angelina Johnson, in her way.

Yes. Re-read the descriptions of Rita Skeeter, for instance. She’s described as having a square jaw, wide shoulders, and large hands. She illegally transforms herself so she can spy on children. She’s exactly the sort of person that JK thinks of when she thinks of trans folk, manipulative, lying about who they are, and a danger to children.

No. There is nothing in the Harry Potter series that suggests transphobia. Rowling does not publish her works through her own political views, least of all Harry Potter. Harry Potter is a series aimed at children, and the closest to any sort of LGBTQI-phobia we have is in chapter one of Order of the Phoenix, when Dudley taunts Harry about Cedric, asking if Cedric was Harry’s boyfriend. But that doesn’t even come remotely close to anything phobic.
